gui

Class Window

  • java.lang.Object
    • gui.Window

  • public class Window
extends Object
    A class for creating simple GUIs (graphical user interfaces). Every instance represents a separate Window. The programmer can display content in the window by drawing on a canvas using draw...() and fill...() methods. Note that the content of the canvas is not displayed immediately, but only after a call to open() or refresh(int).

    There are two ways to use this class. The first way is for displaying static content. First, draw the content using the various draw...() or fill...() methods, then, open the window with open(), and finally, call waitUntilClosed(): 

     Window window = new Window("Pixels", width, height);
 window.drawString(x, y, "Hello World!");
 window.open();
 window.waitUntilClosed();
    The second way is for displaying dynamic and possibly interactive content. First, open the window and then, draw and call refresh(int) in a loop: 
     Window window = new Window("Pixels", width, height);
 window.open();
 while (window.isOpen()) {
     window.drawString(x, y, "Hello World!");
     window.refresh(20);
 }
    All methods of this class use a pixel-based coordinate system with the origin in the upper-left corner of the window. The x-axis extends to the right while the y-axis extends to the bottom of the window. Note that, on high-DPI monitors, one pixel in the window coordinate system may correspond to multiple actual pixels on the monitor.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Window

        public Window(String title,
              int width,
              int height)
        Create a new window with the specified title, width, and height.

    • Method Detail

      • open

        public void open()
        Opens the window and displays the current content of the canvas.

      • close

        public void close()
        Closes the window.

      • isOpen

        public boolean isOpen()
        Returns true if the window is currently open, false otherwise. Note that the window can be closed either by the programmer (by calling close()) or by the user.

      • waitUntilClosed

        public void waitUntilClosed()
        This method returns only once the window is closed by the user (or if it was not open in the first place). More precisely, this method returns, as soon as isOpen() returns true.

      • refresh

        public void refresh()
        Displays the current content of the canvas. Use this method in a loop, together with isOpen(): 
         while(window.isOpen()) {
     ...
     window.refresh();
 }
        In addition, this method also clears the was...Pressed() and was...Clicked() input events.

        Note that this method is equivalent to refresh(0).

        See Also:
        refreshAndClear()

      • refresh

        public void refresh(int waitTime)
        Displays the current content of the canvas. To achieve a constant time interval between iterations, this method does not return until the given waitTime (in milliseconds) has elapsed since the last refresh. For example, to get a frame rate of 50 frames per second, use a waitTime of 1000 / 50 = 20 milliseconds: 
         while(window.isOpen()) {
     ...
     window.refresh(20);
 }
        In addition, this method also clears the was...Pressed() and was...Clicked() input events.
        See Also:
        refreshAndClear(int)

      • refreshAndClear

        public void refreshAndClear()
        Displays the current content of the canvas, clears the was...Pressed() and was...Clicked() input events, and then clears the canvas for the next iteration. Call this method instead of refresh() if every frame is drawn from scratch.

        Note that this method is equivalent to refreshAndClear(0).

      • refreshAndClear

        public void refreshAndClear(int waitTime)
        Displays the current content of the canvas, clears the was...Pressed() and was...Clicked() input events, and then clears the canvas for the next iteration. Call this method instead of refresh(int) if every frame is drawn from scratch. To achieve a constant time interval between iterations, this method does not return until the given waitTime (in milliseconds) has elapsed since the last refresh.

      • setResizable

        public void setResizable(boolean resizable)
        If resizable is true, this window can be resized by the user. By default, windows are non-resizable.

        For resizable windows, use getWidth() and getHeight() to get the current window size.

      • getWidth

        public double getWidth()
        Returns the current window width.

      • getHeight

        public double getHeight()
        Returns the current window height (excluding any title bar added by the operating system).

      • addComponent

        public void addComponent(Component component)
        Adds component to this window. Whenever one of the refresh() methods is called, first the events for Interactive components (e.g. onMouseEnter()) are fired and then Drawable components are drawn.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if component is null or already added.
        See Also:
        removeComponent(Component)

      • removeComponent

        public void removeComponent(Component component)
        Removes component from this window.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if component is null not previously added.
        See Also:
        addComponent(Component)

      • setColor

        public void setColor(int red,
                     int green,
                     int blue)
        Sets the color for the subsequent drawing operations. The three parameters represent the red, green, and blue channel and are expected to be in the 0–255 range. Values outside this range will be clamped. The default color is black (0, 0, 0).

      • setColor

        public void setColor(Color color)
        Sets the color for the subsequent drawing operations, using a Color object. The default color is black (0, 0, 0).

      • getColor

        public Color getColor()
        Returns the current drawing color.

      • setStrokeWidth

        public void setStrokeWidth(double strokeWidth)
        Sets the stroke width for subsequent draw...() operations, in pixels. The default stroke width is 1 pixel.

      • getStrokeWidth

        public double getStrokeWidth()
        Returns the current stroke width (in pixels).

      • setRoundStroke

        public void setRoundStroke(boolean roundStroke)
        If roundStroke is true, subsequent draw...() operations will use round stroke caps and joins instead of flat caps and miter joins.

      • setFontSize

        public void setFontSize(int fontSize)
        Sets the font size for subsequent drawString(String, double, double) operations, in points. The default font size is 11 points.

      • getFontSize

        public int getFontSize()
        Returns the current font size, in points.

      • setBold

        public void setBold(boolean bold)
        If bold is true, subsequent drawString(String, double, double) operations will use a bold font.

      • drawRect

        public void drawRect(double x,
                     double y,
                     double width,
                     double height)
        Draws the outline of a rectangle with the upper-left corner at (x, y) and the given width and height. The current color and stroke width are used.

      • drawOval

        public void drawOval(double x,
                     double y,
                     double width,
                     double height)
        Draws the outline of an oval with a rectangular bounding box that has the upper-left corner at (x, y) and the given width and height. The current color and stroke width are used.

      • drawCircle

        public void drawCircle(double centerX,
                       double centerY,
                       double radius)
        Draws the outline of a circle with the center at (x, y) and the given radius. The current color and stroke width are used.

      • drawLine

        public void drawLine(double x1,
                     double y1,
                     double x2,
                     double y2)
        Draws a line from (x1, y1) to (x2, y2). The current color and stroke width are used.

      • drawString

        public void drawString(String string,
                       double x,
                       double y)
        Draw the given string with the current color. The baseline of the first character is at position (x, y).

      • drawStringCentered

        public void drawStringCentered(String string,
                               double x,
                               double y)
        Draw the given string with the current color. The center of the baseline is at position (x, y).

      • drawImage

        public void drawImage(String path,
                      double x,
                      double y)
        Draws the image found at the given path with the upper-left corner at position (x, y).

        For homework submissions, put all images in the project directory and refer to them using relative paths (i.e., not starting with "C:\" or "/"). For example, an image called "image.jpg" in the project folder can be referred to simply using the path "image.jpg". If you put the image into a subfolder, e.g., "images", refer to it using the path "images/image.jpg". Also, make sure to commit all required images to the SVN repository.

      • drawImageCentered

        public void drawImageCentered(String path,
                              double x,
                              double y)
        Draws the image found at the given path with the center at position (x, y).

        Also, see drawImage(String, double, double).

      • drawImage

        public void drawImage(String path,
                      double x,
                      double y,
                      double scale)
        Draws the image found at the given path with the upper-left corner at position (x, y) and scales it by the given scale. For example, a scale of 2.0 doubles the size of the image.

        Also, see drawImage(String, double, double).

      • drawImageCentered

        public void drawImageCentered(String path,
                              double x,
                              double y,
                              double scale)
        Draws the image found at the given path with the center at position (x, y) and scales it by the given scale. For example, a scale of 2.0 doubles the size of the image.

        Also, see drawImage(String, double, double).

      • drawImageCentered

        public void drawImageCentered(String path,
                              double x,
                              double y,
                              double scale,
                              double angle)
        Draws the image found at the given path with the center at position (x, y), scales it by the given scale and rotates it by the given angle, in radians (0–2×π).

        Also, see drawImage(String, double, double).

      • fillRect

        public void fillRect(double x,
                     double y,
                     double width,
                     double height)
        Fills a rectangle that has the upper-left corner at (x, y) and the given width and height with the current color.

      • fillOval

        public void fillOval(double x,
                     double y,
                     double width,
                     double height)
        Fills an oval with the current color. The oval has a rectangular bounding box with the upper-left corner at (x, y) and the given width and height

      • fillCircle

        public void fillCircle(double centerX,
                       double centerY,
                       double radius)
        Fills a circle that has the center at (x, y) and the given radius with the current color.

      • getPressedKeys

        public List<String> getPressedKeys()

      • getTypedKeys

        public List<String> getTypedKeys()

      • isKeyPressed

        public boolean isKeyPressed(String keyName)
        Returns whether the key specified by the given keyText is currently pressed. Use getPressedKeys() to find out the names for your keys.

      • wasKeyTyped

        public boolean wasKeyTyped(String keyName)
        Returns whether the key specified by the given keyText was just typed (released). Use getPressedKeys() to find out the names for your keys.

      • isLeftMouseButtonPressed

        public boolean isLeftMouseButtonPressed()
        Returns whether the left mouse button is currently pressed. Use getMouseX() and getMouseY() to get the current mouse position.
        See Also:
        isRightMouseButtonPressed()

      • isRightMouseButtonPressed

        public boolean isRightMouseButtonPressed()
        Returns whether the right mouse button is currently pressed. Use getMouseX() and getMouseY() to get the current mouse position.
        See Also:
        isLeftMouseButtonPressed()

      • wasLeftMouseButtonClicked

        public boolean wasLeftMouseButtonClicked()
        Returns whether the left mouse button was just clicked (released). Use getMouseX() and getMouseY() to get the current mouse position.
        See Also:
        wasRightMouseButtonClicked()

      • wasRightMouseButtonClicked

        public boolean wasRightMouseButtonClicked()
        Returns whether the right mouse button was just clicked (released). Use getMouseX() and getMouseY() to get the current mouse position.
        See Also:
        wasLeftMouseButtonClicked()

      • getMouseX

        public double getMouseX()
        Returns the x coordinate of the current mouse position within the window.
        See Also:
        getMouseY()

      • getMouseY

        public double getMouseY()
        Returns the y coordinate of the current mouse position within the window.
        See Also:
        getMouseX()
